story:
Once upon a time, in the beautiful West African country of Mali, there was a small village nestled on the banks of the Niger River. This village was known far and wide for its magnificent cotton trees, which provided shade and shelter to its inhabitants and visitors alike. The villagers took great pride in their trees, and none more so than the wise old elder, Kante.

Kante was a kind and gentle man, loved and respected by all who knew him. He had a long white beard, and his eyes sparkled with the wisdom of the ages. His favorite pastime was to sit beneath the oldest and largest cotton tree in the village, a tree so vast that it took ten men with outstretched arms to encircle its mighty trunk.

One day, as Kante sat beneath the tree, enjoying the cool breeze that rustled its leaves, a small bird fluttered down and alighted on a nearby branch. The bird, a beautiful golden-winged sparrow, chirped happily and looked at Kante with bright, curious eyes.

Kante smiled at the bird, and, feeling a sudden urge to share a story, he began to speak.

"Long ago, in this very place, there lived a mighty hunter named Soumaoro. Soumaoro was strong and fearless, and his fame as a hunter traveled far and wide. But Soumaoro was not content with just hunting animals. He longed for more power and more wealth, and so he began to conquer the neighboring villages and take their riches for his own.

"The other villagers, afraid of Soumaoro's wrath, refused to stand up to him. But one day, a young man named Sundiata arose from the village of Kiri. Sundiata was born with a hunched back and a weak leg, and because of this, he was often overlooked and underestimated. But Sundiata was determined to put an end to Soumaoro's reign of terror.

"Sundiata trained day and night, honing his hunting skills and building his strength. And when he was ready, he gathered an army of brave and noble warriors and set out to find Soumaoro.

"The battle between Soumaoro and Sundiata was fierce and long. Soumaoro wielded powerful magic, and he summoned lightning and thunder to strike down Sundiata and his army. But Sundiata was not deterred. He rallied his warriors, and together they fought with courage and determination.

"In the end, Sundiata triumphed over Soumaoro, and the villagers hailed him as a hero. Sundiata became the new ruler, and he vowed to use his power to protect and serve his people, rather than to oppress them.

"And so, my little friend," Kante concluded, looking down at the golden-winged sparrow, "the story of Soumaoro and Sundiata serves as a reminder that sometimes the most unlikely of heroes can arise to triumph over adversity, and that true strength lies not in physical power, but in courage and determination."

The golden-winged sparrow chirped in agreement, and then flew off, leaving Kante alone beneath the cotton tree once more.

And as Kante closed his eyes, he smiled, knowing that the stories of his ancestors would live on, passed down from generation to generation, just as he had done that day.

The end.

I hope you and your son enjoys this story . Goodnight!
